meanings.definition: To load (a gun) again with ammunition.
meanings.sent1: After shooting all the bullets, he had to reload the gun.
meanings.sent2: The soldier quickly learned how to reload his weapon during training.
meanings.sent3: The cowboy had to reload his gun before the duel, but he accidentally dropped the bullets!
meanings.sent4: She had to reload her arguments in the debate to counter her opponent's points.
meanings.sent5: The hunter's hands moved swiftly to reload the rifle as the bear charged towards him.

meanings.definition: To refresh or update a webpage or document.
meanings.sent1: If the webpage doesn't show the latest news, you may need to reload it.
meanings.sent2: Don't forget to reload the page to see the changes made by your team.
meanings.sent3: The student tried to reload the webpage, but the Wi-Fi was too slow.
meanings.sent4: She had to reload the document multiple times to see the edits her colleague made.
meanings.sent5: The teacher asked the students to reload the online quiz to submit their answers.

meanings.sent1: The chef had to reload the ingredients for the popular dish.
meanings.sent2: It's important to reload the pantry regularly to avoid running out of essentials.
meanings.sent3: The hiker realized he needed to reload his backpack with snacks for the long trek.
meanings.sent4: She had to reload the shelves with new products after the big sale.
meanings.sent5: The store manager instructed the staff to reload the display with fresh produce.
